title.narrative: FAO - Building Resilience in Middle Shabelle ( “BRiMS” ) 2018-2022
FAO- Building Resilience in Middle Shabelle ( “BRiMS” ) 2018-2022

description.narrative: BRiMS projektet kommer bidra till att öka motståndskraften hos utsatta människors försörjning till matosäkerhetskriser genom att hantera de bakomliggande orsaker till sårbarhet i Middle Shabelle, Somalia. Fokus området i BRiMS projektet har utsatts för återkommande torka och översvämningar. Bristen på befintlig och fungerande bevattningsinfrastruktur, utbredd osäkerhet och tillgångsutmaningar är andra utmaningar i Midle Shabelle som hämmar jordbrukarnas produktion och resulterar i försvagad motstråndskraft hos befolkningen. I ljuset av de senaste, återkommande torka och översvämningar, är den huvudsakliga fokuset på detta projekt kring vattenfrågor och bevattning: främst tillgång till vatten samt dess förvaltning.

The project will substantially increase the resilience of vulnerable people’s livelihoods to food crises by addressing key underlying causes of vulnerability in Middle Shabelle, within Somalia’s breadbasket. The area faces recurrent drought, flooding, non-functioning irrigation infrastructure, widespread insecurity and access challenges that impede farmers’ production, related supply chains and market potential. In light of recent, recurrent drought and flood emergencies, the main vulnerability addressed by the project centres on water: primarily water access, management and its productive use.

tag.narrative: 2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: 12768 - Decision on 2nd contribution amendment for FAO BRIMS

description.narrative:
The following have been the key results achieved in the period between 12 Dec 2019 to 30 June 2021:
1. Substantial increase of irrigation water by rehabilitation of 2 main canals of length 23.75 km (Gomey 13.5 km and Kalundi 10.25 km primary canals) and a total number of 10 ancillary structures under the two rehabilitated canals. Remaining canals will be completed in 2021. 2. Approximately 10,000 hectares of farmland are being served by canal water as a result of rehabilitated irrigation networks. 3.Strengthening of 66 river embankments along the river that significantly reduced the impact of flooding particularly in Beletweyne. 4. Improved village connection by providing safe, year-round access to farms, markets, schools, and health care through the rehabilitation of 10 crossing structures in the project command area. 5. Formalization of irrigation water management by strengthening and training irrigation management committees on water management, public asset management and water resource conflict management. 6. Farmer group cooperatives established and organized into productive and profitable groups. 7. Enhanced and strengthened capacity of federal and state level MoAI through training to deliver services to water management committees.
Unexpected but important results included:
1. Though there have been coordination challenges amongst key actors, the efforts of the Hirshabelle State to proactively mitigate flood is to be applauded. The collaboration by the government with community, private sector, United Nations (particularly FAO and OCHA) as well as NGOs on flood mitigation has been an early success of Beletweyne flood prevention. There is need to continue this collaborative approach across Hirshabelle State to extend flood mitigation to other high risk locations.
2. Another notable achievement has been the active community participation and efforts to address 2 critical flood sites in Jowhar using their own resources that had not been part of the project's initial flood assessment. FAO was able to support the community efforts with additional reinforcements to strengthen the embankments.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
